name: Foundations of Political Economy
long_desc: Political Economics studies the interplay between economics and politics. Politicians, for example, may deviate from welfaremaximizing policies due to political pressures. Conversely, the economic and political consequences of policy decisions can shape the choices of future governments. The course will provide a broad, accessible introduction to the key issues in micro and macroeconomics, international economics, and financial markets, emphasizing those most valuable to understanding the interaction of politics and economics. The course will examine core economic concepts to illuminate how economies work, what constraints governments face, and what the welfare implications are of policy choices. From there, the course with incorporate the effect of political actors on economic policy decisionmaking and outcomes. The institutional configurations within countries can fundamentally affect the economic and political decisions available to actors. The course will analyze the various institutional settings and their effects on economic policymaking and outcomes. The course will explore the relationship between politics and economics by examining monetary policy and central banking, economic crises, the international factors influencing the implementation of domestic policies, and political influences on economic integration.

custom_fields.goals: Give students the foundational knowledge of economic concepts which are necessary for a deeper understanding of political economy studies. Facilitate interpretation of current events involving political economy implications. Develop presentation skills.
custom_fields.key_topics: Micro and Macroeconomics; International Economics (Trade and Finance); Banking and Financial Markets
custom_fields.assessment_structure: Two exams, short writing assignments, quizzes, and a group presentation
custom_fields.relevance: Students interested in how politics and economics influence each other in the determination of policy and outcomes.
